content.description:
“The brutal attacks on New York and Washington [on September 11, 2001] did, however, bring a tidal wave of renewed visibility and leverage to the presidential office. President [George W.] Bush’s standing to lead soared, and he seized the reins. On a variety of fronts, legislators hastened to expand his authority. With just one dissenting vote in either chamber . . . Congress passed a resolution on September 14, 2001, stating that ‘the president has authority under the Constitution to take action to deter and prevent acts of international terrorism against the United States.’ . . . Overall, Bush received historically high levels of legislative support throughout his first term. As 2006 began he had yet to veto a single bill, this five-year streak the longest since Thomas Jefferson’s administration.”
Andrew Rudalevige, political scientist, “The Contemporary Presidency,” Presidential Studies Quarterly, 2006
content.question: Which of the following most directly resulted from the events described in the excerpt?

choices.label: United States peacekeeping missions in eastern Europe and Africa
United States launching wars in Afghanistan and Iraq
The mediation between Israel and Egypt by the United States
The end of the Cold War between the Soviet Union and the United States

content.answer: United States launching wars in Afghanistan and Iraq

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Identify a historical concept, development, or process.
